Orders for the use of a restraint shall be time specific.
A resident may not remain in a restraint for more than 2 hours without a change in position and toileting opportunity.
If an order for the use of a restraint is to be continued, the order shall be renewed at least every 7 calendar days by a physician.
The delegating nurse shall provide training to staff in the appropriate use of the restraint ordered by the physician.

Bed Rails. Bed rails may be considered a restraint depending upon the reason for the use of bed rails and how the bed rails are used. This determination is based upon the resident and the effect that bed rails would have upon the resident, as documented in the resident’s record.
The program shall notify the resident’s family or the resident representative each time a restraint is used.

When the resident is under the care of a general hospice care program licensed by the Department and is physically located in an assisted living program licensed by the Department, the general hospice program and the assisted living program shall comply with the requirements of this chapter, COMAR 10.07.21, and federal regulations.

section.heading: Protection of a Resident’s Personal Funds.

para.text: A resident may:
Manage the resident’s financial affairs; or
Consistent with State law, choose any individual who is willing and able to handle the resident’s financial affairs.
An assisted living program may refuse to handle a resident’s financial affairs.
An assisted living program may not manage a resident’s funds without an express written request from the:
Resident; or
Resident agent.

Management of Personal Funds. On the written authorization of a resident or resident agent, an assisted living program shall hold, safeguard, manage, and account for the resident’s personal funds as specified in this regulation.
Safeguards Required.
Each assisted living program shall develop adequate safeguards to secure the personal funds of a resident that are entrusted to the assisted living program.

An assisted living program to which $300 or more of a resident’s personal funds is entrusted shall deposit the money in an interest-bearing bank account. If an assisted living program is entrusted with a resident’s personal funds that are less than $300, the assisted living program may deposit the funds in a bank account.
An assisted living program that manages residents’ personal funds, regardless of the amount managed, shall maintain on behalf of the residents:
A bond, with the State as obligee, equal to the average monthly balance of all the funds held or managed by the assisted living program for the residents of the facility;
A letter of credit, with the State as obligee, equal to the average monthly balance of all the funds held or managed by the assisted living program for the residents of the facility; or
Net assets equal to the average monthly balance of all the funds held or managed by the assisted living program for the residents of the facility.
The bond, letter of credit, or list of assets shall be kept at the assisted living program for inspection by the Department or its designee.
Establishment of Resident Accounts.
When an assisted living program manages a resident’s financial affairs, the assisted living program shall:

Establish and maintain a system that ensures a full, complete, and separate accounting, in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, of a resident’s personal funds entrusted to the assisted living program; and
Keep the accounts of its residents separate from the accounts of the facility.
Bank accounts opened for residents’ personal funds by an assisted living program shall have minimal or no fees.
Any interest earned on the bank accounts shall accrue to the resident.
Any fees charged by the bank for the maintenance of the account shall be paid by the resident.
Records of Resident Personal Funds. For all resident funds entrusted to an assisted living program, the assisted living program shall:
Maintain an individual record for each resident, which includes the following information for each transaction:
The date of the transaction;
The type of transaction, that is, whether it is a deposit, withdrawal, or any other transaction; and
The balance of funds after the completion of the transaction;
Make available for inspection by the resident, or, when applicable, the resident agent or resident representative, a statement of the resident’s account; and

Make available at the assisted living program, for audit by the Department or its designee, records pertaining to each resident’s personal funds, including the written authorization required by §D of this regulation.

Fire and Theft Coverage. For all resident funds entrusted to an assisted living program, the assisted living program shall establish and maintain adequate fire and theft coverage to protect a resident’s funds that are on the premises of the assisted living program.
Availability of Personal Funds.
A resident or, if applicable, the resident’s legally authorized representative, has the right to access funds entrusted to the assisted living program:
During normal business hours, if the funds are held within the facility; or
Within 3 banking days, if a bank, the State, or a county or municipal treasurer holds the money.
If an assisted living program transfers or discharges a resident, the assisted living program shall:
Request and follow the resident’s written instructions for transferring the resident’s funds;

Return, upon the resident’s or, when applicable, the resident agent’s demand, the resident’s money that the assisted living program has in its possession and have the resident or resident agent sign a receipt for the money; or
Make available to the resident or the resident agent, within 3 banking days, the resident’s money which is held in an account with a bank, the State, or a county or municipal treasurer.
Ownership Change.

If the ownership of an assisted living program changes, the previous owner, with the approval of each resident, shall give the new owner a certified written audit of all funds that residents have entrusted to the assisted living program.
The new owner shall give to the previous owner a signed receipt acknowledging the receipt of the accounts.
The new owner shall comply with the safeguard requirements of §E of this regulation.

If the resident wants the new owner to hold, safeguard, manage, or account for the residents personal funds, then a new written authorization in compliance with §D of this regulation shall be executed.
Resident Liability. A resident is not liable for any act or omission of the assisted living program concerning the finances of the assisted living program or the resident.

A person may not misappropriate a resident’s assets or income, including spending the resident’s assets or income against or without the consent of the resident or, if the resident is unable to consent, the resident agent.
An individual who witnessed, or otherwise has reason to believe, that there has been an abuse of a resident’s funds shall make a complaint within 24 hours to the:
Appropriate law enforcement agency;
Office of Health Care Quality of the Department;
Ombudsman within the Department of Aging or local area agency on aging; and
Local Department of Human Services or Adult Protective Services.

The agency that investigates the abuse of a resident’s funds shall send a report to any other agency listed under §B of this regulation that participates in the licensure or subsidizes the care of the resident. Any agency may make a referral to the State’s Attorney’s Office, or to the Medicaid Fraud Control Unit of the Criminal Division of the Office of the Attorney General, if appropriate.

section.heading: Approval of Burial Arrangements for Unclaimed Deceased Residents.

para.text: An assisted living program shall ascertain and document on admission of the resident, or within 14 calendar days of admission, any arrangements the resident has made, or wishes to make, with regard to burial, including, but not limited to:
Financial;
Religious;
Name of preferred funeral director, if any; and
The name, address, and relationship of any person who has agreed to claim the body of the resident or who has agreed to assume funeral or burial responsibility.

Notification on Death. On the death of an individual who appears to be an unclaimed deceased resident, the assisted living manager or designee shall contact any person who, although not having been identified in advance as being responsible for the burial arrangements, might nevertheless at the time of death be willing to claim the body and assume responsibility.
The facility and exterior grounds, shall be kept:
In good repair;
Clean;
Free of any object, material, or condition that may create a health hazard, accident, or fire;
Free of any object, material, or condition that may create a public nuisance; and
Free of insects and rodents.
Bathtubs, shower stalls, and lavatories may not be used by the staff for laundering or storing soiled linens.
The assisted living program shall provide in the resident’s room adequate storage space for excess supplies, some personal possessions of residents, and similar items which is:
Protected from the elements; and
Secure, fixed, and locked in a manner that the resident can access without assistance or with that level of assistance normally required and readily available upon request.

Residents may possess their own cleaning supplies and personal hygiene items if the assisted living manager and delegating nurse have determined that the products would not present a threat to the safety of the resident or others and this decision is documented in the records. The cleaning supplies and personal hygiene items shall be kept in the resident’s room and out of view of other residents when the materials are not in use.

Approved Source. A facility shall be served by water from an approved public water supply. If an approved public water supply is not available, a private water supply may be accepted if it is approved by the local jurisdiction in which the program is located or a private certified vendor to be submitted with an initial licensure application.
Adequacy. The water supply shall be adequate in quantity and delivered under sufficient pressure to satisfactorily serve all fixtures in the facility.

Hot Water Temperature. Hot water accessible to residents shall be blended externally to the hot water generator, by either individual point-of-use control valves of the anti-scald or thermostatic mixing valve type, to a maximum temperature of 120°F and a minimum temperature of 100°F at the fixture.

section.heading: Sewage Disposal.
section.text: The facility shall be served by an approved public sewage disposal system, if available. If an approved public sewage disposal system is not available, a private sewage disposal system may be accepted if approved by the local jurisdiction in which the program is located.

para.text: The facility shall provide:
Lockable exterior doors and windows; and
An effective automated device or system to alert staff to individuals entering or leaving the building.

A facility need not use an automated alert for an exit door when the exit is staffed by a receptionist or other staff member who views and maintains a log of individuals entering and leaving the facility.

An assisted living program shall provide assist rails in stairways used by residents and for all toilets, showers, and bathtubs used by residents unless, through a waiver request, the Department determines that the physical abilities of the residents make these devices unnecessary for resident safety.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds shall also provide assist rails on both sides of corridors used by residents.
The facility shall comply with:
All applicable local fire and building codes; and
The National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) 101 Life Safety Code, including Chapter 24 of NFPA 101 if the facility is a one or two family dwelling as defined by NFPA 101.
Fire Extinguishers. An assisted living program shall:
Ensure that fire extinguishers are:
Located on each floor and adjacent to, or in, special hazard areas, such as:
Furnace rooms;
Boiler rooms;
Kitchens; or
Laundries;
Of standard and approved types;
Installed and maintained to be conveniently available for use at all times; and
Serviced annually, as evidenced by documentation maintained on-site, by an individual or company licensed by the Maryland State Fire Marshall; and
Initially and at least annually instruct staff in the use of fire extinguishers.
Emergency and Disaster Plan.

The assisted living program shall develop an Assisted Living Emergency Preparedness Packet in compliance with the requirements of §C(2)—(11) of this regulation, which shall be readily available to all staff.
The assisted living program shall develop an emergency and disaster plan that includes procedures that shall be followed before, during, and after an emergency or disaster, including:
Evacuation, transportation, or sheltering in-place of residents;
Notification of families and staff regarding the action that will be taken concerning the safety and well-being of the residents;

Staff coverage, organization, and assignment of responsibilities for ongoing sheltering in-place or evacuation, including identification of staff members available to report to work or remain for extended periods; and
The continuity of services, including:
Operations, planning, financial, and logistical arrangements;
Procuring essential goods, equipment, and services to sustain operations for at least 72 hours;
Relocation to alternate facilities or other locations; and
Reasonable efforts to continue care.
The assisted living program shall have a tracking system to locate and identify residents in the event of displacement, an emergency, or a disaster that includes at a minimum the:
Resident’s name;
Date and time that the resident was sent to the initial alternative facility or location;
Name of the initial alternative facility or location where the resident was sent; and
Contact person and phone number for the facility where the resident was sent.
When the assisted living program relocates residents, the assisted living program shall send a brief medical fact sheet with each resident that includes at a minimum the resident’s:
Name;
Medical condition or diagnosis;
Medications;
Allergies;
Special diets or dietary restrictions; and
Family or legal representative contact information.
The brief medical fact sheet for each resident described in §C(4) of this regulation shall be:
Updated upon the occurrence of change in any of the required information;
Reviewed at least monthly; and
Maintained in a central location readily accessible and available to accompany residents in case of an emergency evacuation.
The assisted living program shall review the emergency and disaster plan at least annually and update the plan as necessary.
The assisted living program shall:
Identify a facility, facilities, or an alternate location or locations that have agreed to house the licensee’s residents during an emergency evacuation; and
Document an agreement with each facility or location.
The assisted living program shall:
Identify a source or sources of transportation that have agreed to safely transport residents during an emergency evacuation; and
Document an agreement with each transportation source.

Upon request, an assisted living program shall provide a copy of the facility’s emergency and disaster plan to the local emergency management organization for the purpose of coordinating local emergency planning. The assisted living program shall provide the emergency and disaster plan in a format that is mutually agreeable to the local emergency management organization.

The assisted living program shall identify an emergency and disaster planning liaison for the facility and shall provide the liaison’s contact information to the local emergency management organization.

The assisted living program shall prepare an executive summary of its evacuation procedures to provide to a resident, family member, or legal representative upon request. The executive summary shall, at a minimum:
List means of potential transportation to be used in the event of evacuation;
List potential alternative facilities or locations to be used in the event of evacuation;
Describe means of communication with family members and legal representatives;
Describe the role of the resident, family member, or legal representative in the event of an emergency situation; and
Notify families that the information provided may change depending upon the nature or scope of the emergency or disaster.
Evacuation Plans. The facility shall:
Conspicuously post individual floor plans with designated evacuation routes on each floor; and
Ensure that all staff have access to the entire emergency preparedness plan.
Orientation and Drills.
The assisted living program shall:
Orient staff to the emergency and disaster plan and to their individual responsibilities within 24 hours of the commencement of job duties; and
Document completion of the orientation in the staff member’s personnel file through the signature of the employee.
Fire Drills.
The assisted living program shall conduct fire drills at least quarterly on all shifts.
Documentation and Retention. The assisted living program shall document and maintain on file for a minimum of 2 years the:
Completion date and time of each drill;
Names and signatures of staff who participated in the drill;
Fire scenario used in the drill;
Steps taken by staff during the drill;
Successful and non-successful actions taken by staff during the drill; and
Opportunities for improvement identified as a result of the drill.
Semiannual Disaster Drill.

The assisted living program shall conduct a semiannual emergency and disaster drill on all shifts during which it practices evacuating residents or sheltering in-place so that each is practiced at least one time a year.
The drills may be conducted via a table-top exercise if the program can demonstrate that moving residents will be harmful to the residents.
The assisted living program shall document and keep on file for a minimum of 2 years the:
Completion date and time of each disaster drill or training session;
Names and signature of staff who participated in the drill or training;
Type of disaster utilized for the drill or training;
Type of drill or training undertaken;
Steps taken or discussed by staff during the drill or training;
Successful and non-successful actions taken or discussed by staff during the drill or training; and
Opportunities for improvement as identified as a result of the drill.
The assisted living program shall cooperate with the local emergency management agency in emergency planning, training, and drills and in the event of an actual emergency.
Emergency Electrical Power Generator.

Generator Required. By October 1, 2009, an assisted living program with 50 or more residents shall have an emergency electrical power generator on the premises, unless the program meets the requirements of §F(7) of this regulation.
Generator Specifications. The power source shall be a generating set and prime mover located on the program’s premises with automatic transfer. The emergency generator shall:
Be activated immediately when normal electrical service fails to operate;
Come to full speed and load acceptance within 10 seconds; and
Have the capability of 48 hours of operation of the systems listed in §F(5) of this regulation from fuel stored on-site.
Test of Emergency Power System.
The program shall test the emergency power system once each month.
During testing of the emergency power system, the generator shall be exercised for a minimum of 30 minutes under normal emergency facility connected load.
Results of the test shall be recorded in a permanent log book that is maintained for that purpose.
The assisted living program shall monitor the fuel level of the emergency generator after each test.
The emergency power system shall provide lighting in the following areas of the facility:
Areas of egress and protection as required by the State Fire Prevention Code and Life Safety Code 101 as adopted by the State Fire Prevention Commission;
Nurses’ station;
Medication distribution station or unit dose storage;
An area for emergency telephone use;
Boiler or mechanical room;
Kitchen;
Emergency generator location and switch gear location;
Elevator, if operable on emergency power;
Areas where life support equipment is used;
If applicable, common areas or areas of refuge; and
If applicable, toilet rooms of common areas or areas of refuge.
Emergency electrical power shall be provided for the following:
Nurses’ call system;
At least one telephone in order to make and receive calls;
Fire pump;
Well pump;
Sewerage pump and sump pump;
If required for evacuation purposes, an elevator;
If necessary, heating equipment needed to maintain a minimum temperature of 70°F (24°C) in all common areas or areas of refuge;
Life support equipment; and
Nonflammable medical gas systems.

Common Areas or Areas of Refuge. If the emergency power system does not provide heat to all resident rooms and toilet rooms, the program shall provide common areas or areas of refuge for all residents. The areas shall meet the following requirements:
The common area or areas of refuge shall maintain a minimum temperature of 70°F (24°C);
Heated toilet rooms shall be provided adjacent to the common areas or areas of refuge; and
The program facility shall provide to the Department a written plan that defines the:
Specified common areas or areas of refuge;
Paths of egress from the common areas or areas of refuge; and
Provision for light, heat, food service, and washing and toileting of residents.
Applicability of Emergency Power Requirements.

An assisted living program shall be exempt from the requirements of this section if the program can safely transfer residents through an enclosed corridor to a building that is equipped with an electrical power generator that satisfies the requirements of §E of this regulation.

An assisted living program may request a waiver from the requirements of this section in accordance with the procedures outlined in COMAR 10.07.14.09 on a year-to-year basis. The program shall demonstrate in the waiver request financial hardship that would create an undue financial burden on the facility and will require the facility to cease operation of the assisted living program.
When the Department grants a waiver to an assisted living program for the requirements of this section, the assisted living program shall:
Disclose in writing to current and prospective residents that the program does not have an emergency generator; and
Develop a plan to follow in the event of a loss of electrical power.
The assisted living program shall have a written smoking policy that indicates whether or not the program permits smoking.
When smoking is permitted, the assisted living program shall:
Establish smoking policies and procedures which are designed to minimize the risk of fire;
Provide in the policies and procedures at least the following:
Prohibit smoking in any hazardous location and in any room or compartment where flammable liquids, combustible gases, or oxygen are used or stored;
Designate smoking areas; and
Provide the smoking areas with ash trays of noncombustible material and safe design;
Provide smoking areas that comply with all applicable, local, State, and federal regulations;
Assess each resident who smokes to determine if assistance or supervision is needed and document the assessment in the resident’s service plan; and

At least annually or after a change of condition that may impact a resident’s ability to smoke, reassess a resident who smokes to determine if assistance or supervision is needed and document the reassessment in the resident’s service plan.
Multipurpose Space.
The assisted living program shall provide at least 35 square feet of usable multipurpose floor space per licensed bed. Multipurpose space includes:
Dining;
Living; and
Indoor recreational space.
Usable floor space in a facility does not include:
Service areas;
Administrative offices;
Entrance ways;
Closets;
Lockers;
Wardrobes;
Spaces where ceiling heights are less than acceptable for habitable space, as defined by the applicable local building code; or
Corridors.
The assisted living program may not restrict residents from any area constituting multipurpose space unless a comparable multipurpose space is available for resident use.
Living Room.
The assisted living program shall make at least one living room available for resident use.
The assisted living program shall ensure that the living rooms are:
Well lit and ventilated;
Easily accessible; and
Furnished with a sufficient number of reading lamps, tables, chairs, or sofas based on residents’ needs.
Outdoor Space. An assisted living program shall:
Provide or arrange for outside activity space;
Adequately light outside activity space during all times residents have access to the space; and
Provide the necessary security and supervision of the outside activity space sufficient to meet the needs of the residents.
Public Toilets.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds shall provide public restrooms that are:
Sufficient in number, and appropriately located, to serve both residents and visitors; and
Located close enough to activity areas to allow all residents to participate comfortably in activities and social opportunities.
The public toilet is not calculated in the ratio required by Regulation .50A of this chapter.
Dining Room. An assisted living program shall provide a well lit, adequately ventilated, and appropriately furnished dining area.
Kitchen.
An assisted living program shall have a kitchen that has adequate:
Storage, refrigerator, and freezer space for perishable and nonperishable foods;
Food preparation area or areas with cleanable surfaces;
Equipment to deliver foods at safe and palatable temperatures;
Space and equipment to wash, sanitize, and store utensils;
Space to store and clean garbage cans either within or outside the kitchen;
Ice-making capabilities;
Equipment for the preparation of food, unless all food service is catered; and
Equipment for serving and distributing food to residents.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds shall comply with the food service facility regulations in COMAR 10.15.03.

An assisted living program with fewer than 17 residents is not required to comply with COMAR 10.15.03 unless required to comply by its local jurisdiction or the Department determines and directs that a program shall comply with particular provisions of COMAR 10.15.03 in order to minimize health risks to its residents.
An assisted living program with fewer than 17 residents:
Shall obtain food from sources that comply with all laws and regulations relating to food, food processing, food handling, and food labeling;
Shall protect food from contamination while being stored, prepared, displayed, served, or transported;
Shall promptly discard the following:
Spoiled food;
Swelled, rusty, or leaky canned foods; and
Food exposed to fire, smoke, or water damage;

May not serve to residents home-canned food or food in a hermetically sealed container as defined in COMAR 10.15.03.02B, which was prepared in a place other than a licensed food processing establishment;
Shall maintain potentially hazardous food as defined in COMAR 10.15.03.02B at 45°F or below, or 140°F or above, until served to residents;
Shall maintain food equipment, appliances, and utensils in a clean and sanitary manner and in good repair;
Shall maintain food contact surfaces smooth and free of breaks, open seams, cracks, chips, and pits;
Shall maintain floors, walls, and storage areas in a clean and sanitary manner and in good repair;
Shall provide refrigeration operated at or below 45°F and equipped with an indicating thermometer graduated at 2°F intervals; and
Shall provide freezer space operated at 0°F or less and equipped with an indicating thermometer graduated at 2°F intervals.
Resident Room.
More than two residents may not share a resident room.
An assisted living program shall provide at least 80 square feet of functional space for single occupancy resident rooms and 120 square feet of functional space for double occupancy resident rooms.
Functional space in a resident room does not include the floor area of:
Toilet rooms and bathing facilities;
Closets, wardrobes, bureaus, or lockers;
Entrance vestibules; or
The arc of any door, excluding closet doors, that opens into the room.
A room may not be used as a resident room if:
The only access to the room is through a bathroom or other resident room; or
In order to move from the room to a living room or dining room a person must first go outdoors.

For a program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds, a room may not be used as a resident room if in order to move from the room to a living room or dining room, an individual is required to first pass through a kitchen.

Resident rooms shall be for the private use of the assigned resident or residents. A resident’s room shall have a latching door and may have a lock on the resident room side of the door at the licensee’s option.
If a resident in a double occupancy room requests dividers, curtains, or screens between the beds to ensure privacy, the assisted living program shall furnish them.

A resident shall have access to a mirror either in the resident’s room or in the resident’s private bathroom, unless a health care practitioner documents in the resident’s record that access to a mirror would be detrimental to the health of the resident.
A resident’s room shall have window shades or their equivalent.
The assisted living program shall provide adequate closet or wardrobe space, conveniently located to allow each resident to keep personal clothing.
Furnishings. Unless a resident brings personal furnishings, or as otherwise specified in the resident agreement, the assisted living program shall provide the following to each resident:
A bed, which may not be a rollaway, cot, or folding bed, but shall:
Be at least 36 inches wide;
Be in good repair;
Meet the resident’s medical needs; and
Include:
A clean mattress sized to fit the bed frame; and
At least two clean pillows;
A bedside stand with a drawer;
A chair;
At least two dresser drawers in a chest of drawers;
A bedside or over-the-bed lamp; and
A sufficient supply of bath and bed linens.
A competent resident may waive the resident’s right to one or all of the furnishings listed in §B of this regulation by signing a waiver and having the waiver placed in the resident’s record.

The assisted living program shall inform a resident of all of the furnishings that the assisted living program provides. The resident may choose, at their cost, to provide a personal bed or other furnishings if they are not hazardous.
Toilets.
An assisted living program shall provide toilets in a separate room or compartment with latching hardware for privacy.
Buildings with one to eight occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one toilet to four occupants.
Buildings with nine or more occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one toilet to four occupants and a minimum of one toilet for each floor on which a resident room is located.
Hand Sinks.
Buildings with one to eight occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one hand sink to four occupants.
Buildings with nine or more occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one hand sink to four occupants and a minimum of one hand sink for each floor on which a resident room is located.
Bathtubs or Showers. An assisted living program shall:
Provide residents with bathtubs or showers that are enclosed in a separate room or compartment with latching hardware for privacy; and
Have a minimum ratio of one bathtub or shower to eight occupants.
Resident’s Room.
An assisted living program shall ensure that a resident’s room:
Is lighted by an outside window that:
Contains a glass surface; and
Has square footage at least equal to 10 percent of the room’s required floor area;
Has a minimum of 60 watts or the equivalent of artificial light provided for reading; and
Is provided with additional artificial light as required for other uses, such as night lights to enable residents to get to the bathroom at night.
An assisted living program shall provide additional lighting or watts upon reasonable request by the resident or the resident’s legal representative.

Common Use Areas. An assisted living program shall ensure that common use areas, such as entrances, hallways, inclines, ramps, cellars, attics, storerooms, kitchens, and laundries, have sufficient artificial lighting to prevent accidents and promote efficient service.
The assisted living program shall provide sufficient light to meet the resident’s needs.
An assisted living program may not use space heaters unless approved by the State or local fire authorities.
Minimum Temperature. The facility shall have a system that provides in areas used by residents a minimum temperature of 70°F in cold weather and a maximum temperature of 80°F in hot weather.
Temperature Control.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of one to eight beds shall provide at least one thermostat per building.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of nine or more beds shall provide for each resident’s room:
A thermostat; or
An approved mechanical device for modulating a room’s temperature, such as adjustable vanes in a hot air vent.
An assisted living program shall:
Ensure that all rooms and areas have sufficient ventilation to prevent excessive heat, steam, condensation, smoke, and other noxious odors; and
Provide forced mechanical exhaust ventilation or an approved equivalent for:
All bathing compartments;
Toilet rooms;
Any area used for toileting;
Soiled utility rooms;
Designated smoking rooms; and
Other rooms, as determined by the Department.

If steam or hot water plumbing reaches a temperature in excess of 130°F or directly powered radiating surfaces are located in areas of the facility that are accessible to residents, the assisted living program shall position or shield the radiating surfaces in a manner to prevent resident contact.
The assisted living program shall ensure that the radiator shielding device:
Allows for efficient heat transfer;
Is constructed to minimize vermin harborage;
Is constructed of easily cleanable materials; and
Complies with all State and local fire codes.
An assisted living program shall furnish laundry service, either on-site or off-site.
An assisted living program shall ensure that the laundry is:
Adequate to meet the needs of the residents;
Processed and handled in a manner to prevent the spread of infection; and
Adequately sanitized by the use of sufficient hot water or appropriate chemical agents, or a combination of both.
Unless otherwise agreed by the program and the resident, dry cleaning services are not considered part of required laundry services in this chapter.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of one to eight beds shall provide:
At least one common-use telephone for residents; and
A posting next to the common-use telephone or in a conspicuous location that contains the telephone numbers for the local police department and fire department.

An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of nine to 16 beds shall provide at least one common-use telephone. If there are nine or more residents that do not have private telephones in their own rooms, the assisted living program shall provide a second common-use telephone.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds shall provide:
That each resident’s room accommodates the use of the resident’s own private telephone; and
An adequate number of common-use telephones to accommodate those residents who do not have private telephones installed in their rooms.
If the Secretary determines that an assisted living program has violated this chapter, the Secretary, in addition to the sanctions set forth in this chapter, may impose one or more of the following:
Restrict the number of residents the assisted living program may admit in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-328, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Require the assisted living program to reduce the number of residents in care;
Restrict the levels of care for which the assisted living program may provide services;
Require the assisted living program, and any of its staff, to receive remedial instruction in a specific area;
Require the assisted living program to use the services of and cover the costs of a management firm approved by the Department;
Require the assisted living program to use the services of and cover the costs of a consultant to provide expertise related to:
One or more licensure requirements;
Standards of care; or
Discharge planning.
Mandate staffing patterns which specify number of personnel, personnel qualifications, or both;
Require the establishment of an escrow account in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-362, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Direct the assisted living program to correct the violations in a specific manner or within a specified time frame, or both;
Notify, or require the assisted living program to notify, the representative or family of any resident who is affected by the noncompliance;
Increase the frequency of monitoring visits during a specified period of time; or
Enter into an agreement with the assisted living program establishing certain conditions for continued operation, including time limits for compliance.
If the Secretary determines that the assisted living program has violated a condition or requirement of an imposed sanction, the Secretary may suspend or revoke the license.
Appeals.

An assisted living program aggrieved by the imposition of a sanction under §A(1), (2), or (3) or B of this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .65 of this chapter.

An assisted living program aggrieved by the imposition of a sanction under §A(8) of this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action in accordance with Health-General Article, §§19-364 and 19-367, Annotated Code of Maryland.
This section does not, however, create an appeal for a decision made under Regulation .23A of this chapter.
The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty on a person if:
The person maintains or operates an unlicensed assisted living program;
A deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists in the assisted living program; or
The person falsely advertises a program in violation of Regulation .06B(2) of this chapter.
In determining whether a civil money penalty is to be imposed, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:
Nature, number, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The extent to which the deficiency or deficiencies are part of an ongoing pattern during the preceding 24 months;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the program that is caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of the program to correct, the deficiency or deficiencies; and
An assisted living program’s prior history of compliance.
If the Department determines that a deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists, the Department shall notify the program of the deficiency or deficiencies and may:
Impose a per day civil money penalty until sustained compliance has been achieved;
Permit the program the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date; or
Impose a per instance civil money penalty for each instance of violation.

If the Department permits a program the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date, and the program fails to comply with this requirement, the Department may impose a per day civil money penalty for each day of violation until correction of the deficiency or deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
If the Department proposes to impose a civil money penalty, the Secretary shall issue an order which shall state the:
Deficiency or deficiencies on which the order is based;
Amount of civil money penalties to be imposed; and
Manner in which the amount of civil money penalties imposed was calculated.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .65 of this chapter.
A civil money penalty imposed on a person under this chapter may not exceed the amounts identified in Health-General §19-1809, Annotated Code of Maryland.
In setting the amount of the civil money penalty under this chapter, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:
Nature, number, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the program that is caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of, the program to correct the deficiency or deficiencies;
Whether the amount of the civil money penalty will jeopardize the financial ability of the program to continue operation as a program; and
Other factors as justice may require.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .65 of this chapter.
A hearing on the appeal shall be held consistent with the State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Secretary shall have the burden of proof with respect to the imposition of the civil money penalties under this chapter.
Operating Without a License.
A person may not knowingly and willfully operate, maintain, or own an assisted living program without a license.
A person who violates §A(1) of this regulation is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to:
For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $10,000, imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or both; and
For a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $20,000, imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or both.

If the Department finds a credible allegation that an assisted living program is operating without a license, the Department, or the Office of Health Care Quality, shall investigate whether residents in the assisted living program have been subjected to neglect, abuse, or financial exploitation.

On receipt of a credible allegation, or after an investigation that results in a finding that residents in an unlicensed assisted living program have been subjected to neglect, abuse, or financial exploitation, the person operating the unlicensed program shall be subject to immediate prosecution under §A(2) of this regulation.

If the person operating an unlicensed assisted living program fails or refuses to cooperate fully in an investigation by the Department, or the Office of Health Care Quality, conducted under §A(3) of this regulation, the person operating the unlicensed assisted living program shall be subject to immediate prosecution under §A(2) of this regulation.

If the Department finds, after an investigation conducted under §A(3) of this regulation, that there is no reason to believe that residents in the assisted living program operating without a license have been subject to financial exploitation, neglect, or abuse:

The Department shall provide written notice to the unlicensed assisted living program that the program shall come into compliance with licensure requirements within 30 days after receipt of the written notification; and
The person operating the program may not be subject to prosecution under §A(2) of this regulation if the person:
Has promptly and in good faith submitted a complete application to the Department for an assisted living program license;
Is awaiting a decision from the Department regarding the application; and
Has not been denied an assisted living program license on a prior occasion.
In recommending the amount of the criminal penalty under §A(2) of this regulation, the State shall consider factors including the nature, number, and seriousness of the violations.

The Department, the Attorney General, a State’s Attorney, or a local health officer may petition a circuit court for injunctive relief against the operation of an assisted living program operating without a license.
A violation of §A(1) of this regulation shall be a violation of the Consumer Protection Act.
Advertisement and Representation of an Assisted Living Program.

A person may not advertise, represent, or imply to the public that an assisted living program is authorized to provide a service that the program is not licensed, certified, or otherwise authorized by the Department to provide when the license, certificate, or authorization is required under this subtitle.
A person may not advertise an assisted living program in a misleading or fraudulent manner.
A person who violates §B(1) of this regulation is subject to a civil money penalty imposed by the Secretary not exceeding $10,000 for each offense.

In setting the amount of a civil money penalty on the program under §B(1) of this regulation, the Secretary shall consider factors including the nature, number, and seriousness of the violations and the ability of the assisted living program to pay the penalty.
Referral to an Assisted Living Program Operating Without a License.
A person may not willfully and knowingly refer another person to an assisted living program that is operating without a license.
A person who violates §C(1) of this regulation is subject to the following civil penalties:
For a first offense, a civil penalty not exceeding $1,000;
For a second offense, a civil penalty not exceeding $2,000; or
For a third or subsequent offense, a civil penalty not exceeding $3,000.

The Secretary shall remit all civil penalties collected under this regulation to the Office of Health Care Quality for the purposes of carrying out the provisions of Health-General Article, §19–1813, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Department shall establish a health care quality account in the Department for assisted living programs.
The health care quality account shall be funded by civil money penalties paid by assisted living programs.
The Department shall use funds from the health care quality account to improve the quality of care in assisted living programs.
Expenditure of funds may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Funding for the establishment and operation of a demonstration project;
A grant award;
Relocation of residents in crisis situations;
Provision of educational programs to assisted living programs, the Office of Health Care Quality, other government, professional, or advocacy agencies, and consumers; and
Any other purpose that will directly improve quality of care.
Suggestions for the use of funds may be submitted to the Department from:
Members of the public;
Advocacy organizations;
Government agencies;
Professional organizations, including trade associations;
Assisted living programs; and
Assisted living associations.
Decision on Expenditure of Funds.
The Department, in its sole discretion, shall decide how to spend funds from the health care quality account.

The Department’s decision to spend funds or not to spend funds for a specific project or purpose is not a contested case as defined in State Government Article, §10-202(d), Annotated Code of Maryland, and therefore may not be appealed.
The Secretary may immediately suspend a license on finding that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action.
The Department shall deliver a written notice to the assisted living program:
Informing the program of the emergency suspension;
Giving the reasons for the action and the regulation or regulations with which the assisted living program has failed to comply that forms the basis for the emergency suspension; and
Notifying the assisted living program of its right to request a hearing and to be represented by counsel.
The filing of a hearing request does not stay the emergency action.
When a license is suspended by emergency action:
The assisted living program shall immediately cease the use of all previously issued assisted living program licenses and return all paper licenses to the Department;
The assisted living program shall stop providing assisted living services immediately;

The assisted living manager or their designee shall notify the residents and resident representatives of the suspension and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making safe and appropriate discharge plans, including to other licensed assisted living programs; and
The OHCQ shall immediately notify the following entities of the emergency action:
Ombudsman within the Department of Aging or local area agency on aging; and
Local Department of Human Services or Adult Protective Services.
In the event of an emergency suspension, the Department may assist in the relocation of residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing consistent with Regulation .65 of this chapter.
Show Cause Hearing.

In addition to the right to request a hearing consistent with Regulation .65 of this chapter, a person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation shall be provided with the opportunity for a hearing to show cause why the Department should lift the summary suspension.

If requested in writing, the show cause hearing shall be held promptly within a reasonable time after the effective date of the order of summary suspension. The time limit for filing an appeal with the Office of Administrative Hearings to obtain an evidentiary hearing shall be followed by the filing of a request for a show cause hearing.
The show cause hearing shall be a nonevidentiary hearing to provide the parties with an opportunity for oral argument on the summary suspension.
The show cause hearing shall be conducted before the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary, who:
Shall determine procedural issues;
May impose reasonable time limits on each party’s oral argument; and
Shall make rulings reasonably necessary to facilitate the effective and efficient operation of the show cause hearing.
At the conclusion of the show cause hearing, the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee may:
Affirm the order of summary suspension;
Rescind the order of summary suspension;
Enter into a consent order; or
Enter into an interim order warranted by the circumstances of the case, including one providing for a stay of the summary suspension subject to certain conditions.

After the show cause hearing, if the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee decides to continue the summary suspension, the person aggrieved by the decision may request an evidentiary hearing before the Office of Administrative Hearings consistent with Regulation .65 of this chapter.
Hearing.
The Office of Administrative Hearings shall conduct a hearing as provided in Regulation .65 of this chapter and issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
An aggrieved person may file exceptions pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
The Secretary shall make a final decision pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
If the Secretary’s final decision does not uphold the emergency suspension, the assisted living program may resume operation.

The Secretary, for cause shown, may notify the assisted living program of the Secretary’s decision to revoke the assisted living program’s license. The revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested.
The Department shall notify the assisted living program in writing of the following:
The effective date of the revocation;
The reason for the revocation;
The regulations with which the assisted living program has failed to comply that form the basis for the revocation;
That the assisted living program is entitled to a hearing, if requested, and to be represented by counsel;
That the assisted living program shall stop providing services on the effective date of the revocation if the assisted living program does not request a hearing;
That the revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested; and
That the assisted living program is required to surrender its license to the Department if the revocation is upheld.
The assisted living manager or their designee shall:
Notify the residents and residents’ representatives of the revocation;
Make every reasonable effort to assist residents and resident representatives in making safe and appropriate discharge plans, including to other licensed assisted living programs; and
Immediately notify the following entities of the revocation:
Ombudsman within the Department of Aging or local area agency on aging; and
Local Department of Human Services or Adult Protective Services.
OHCQ shall notify the following entities of the revocation:
Ombudsman within the Department of Aging or local area agency on aging; and
Local Department of Human Services or Adult Protective Services.

The Department may assist in the relocation of residents or require the assisted living program to use the services of and cover the costs of a consultant to arrange safe and appropriate discharges for residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary’s action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .65 of this chapter.

A request for a hearing shall be filed with the Office of Administrative Hearings, with a copy to the Office of Health Care Quality of the Department, not later than 30 days after receipt of notice of the Secretary’s action. The request shall include a copy of the Secretary’s action.
A hearing requested under this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.01.03 and 28.02.01.
The burden of proof is as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.28.
Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
The aggrieved person may file exceptions as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.18.
A final decision by the Secretary shall be issued in accordance with COMAR 10.01.03.18J.
